userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: RAC users must abide by all applicable provisions of United States copyright law. Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use." If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the user's responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Material in the Rockefeller family collections that provides the names, correspondence, or activities of living members of the Rockefeller family, and/or documents the net wealth of any Rockefeller family members, is restricted. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged alphabetically by subject.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The central figure in the creation and operation of the Standard Oil Company during its rise to the top of the petroleum industry, John D. Rockefeller (JDR) established for the family a leading role in business and philanthropy. From the days of his earliest employment, Rockefeller, a devout Baptist, was generous in his giving to worthy causes, especially those of a religious nature. During the 1890s he developed an orderly system of philanthropic giving through an office staff that included his close advisor, Frederick T. Gates (1853-1929) and his son, John D. Rockefeller, Jr. (1874-1960). With the advise of these and other associates, Rockefeller established the University of Chicago, The Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research (now The Rockefeller University), the Rockefeller Foundation, and other philanthropic organizations working nationally and internationally in the fields of education, religion, and health. Rockefeller's total donations to philanthropic endeavors are estimated to have been $540 million.

John D. Rockefeller, Jr. (JDR Jr.) joined his father's office on October 1, 1897. He oversaw the expansion and diversification of the philanthropic work begun by his father. During his lifetime, the younger Rockefeller gave more than $537 million to educational, religious, cultural, medical, and other charitable projects.

John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and his wife, Abby Aldrich Rockefeller (1874-1948), passed the Rockefeller philanthropic impulse on to their children. John D. 3rd (1906-1978), Nelson A. (1908-1979), Laurance S. (1910-2004), Winthrop (1912-1973), and David (1915-) further expanded and diversified Rockefeller influence and interests, establishing their own philanthropic organizations, most notably the Rockefeller Brothers Fund (1940), and becoming more active politically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller (OMR) materials document the increasing role assumed by John D. Rockefeller, Jr. in the management of Rockefeller affairs and amply document his business and philanthropic affairs. They also chronicle the entrance of JDR Jr.'s sons, John D. 3rd, Nelson A., Laurance S., Winthrop, and David, into the world of business, philanthropy, civic leadership, and politics as they joined the office.

This material contains correspondence, reports, pamphlets, memoranda, deeds, maps, contracts, reports, minutes, charters, certificates of incorporation, clippings, diaries, notebooks, calendars, and memorabilia.
There is a microfilm card index of personal and institutional names.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of all material relating to John D. Rockefeller that could not be placed in the John D. Rockefeller papers (FA002) due to limitations of date and type of material. Of special interest are the correspondence files, including those related to boards, the Rockefeller family, and investments; and the files on the Forest Hill, Golf House, and Pocantico Hills properties.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller's last dated office letter, June 11, 1897. Foreign decorations; friendly newspaper references; presents from John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Comments on politics. Visitors; memberships; change in residence; increasing weakness with old age. Article about John D. Rockefeller's stock market activity. Gifts of personal jewelry to grandsons. Winston Churchill article on John D. Rockefeller. Death. Recollections of John D. Rockefeller by various people; requests for aid because of old friendships or obligations. Photographs sent to John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Correspondents include Henry M. Flagler, John D. Rockefeller, Frederick T. Gates, Starr J. Murphy, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Robert W. Gumbel, W. Davis, Willard S. Richardson, Thomas M. Debevoise.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller's $32,000,000 gift to General Education Board, large parts of it to go to Rockefeller Institute and University of Chicago. Lists of colleges and amounts donated. John D. Rockefeller Special Fund.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Carrying on work of Hookworm Commission in South - extending help to arrest hookworm in Egypt. Assistance to countries in different parts of the world - yellow fever. Correspondents include Wickliffe Rose, Jerome D. Greene.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed copy of Hearing before Senate committee on bill to incorporate Rockefeller Foundation - Jerome Greene's aid enlisted to help bill through Senate. 1913 bill's defeat in Senate, obtained state charter 1913. How much of a gift should John D. Rockefeller (JDR) give. Asking JDR to become honorary president. Selection of board members. Correspondents include Starr J. Murphy, John D. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Frederick T. Gates, Senator Nelson Aldrich.

did.unittitle: Correspondence - Boards - Rockefeller Foundation - Appropriation Statements

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Broken down into gifts made by Rockefeller Foundation from its own funds and gifts from income reserved by John D. Rockefeller.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Large gifts to Hookworm Commission, missionary work. Idea of establishing China Medical Board, gift.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 1909 copy of Deed of Trust: John D. Rockefeller (JDR) to John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Harold F. McCormick and Frederick T. Gates. 1913 and 1914 gifts of securities. 1914 gift bringing total to $100,000,000. JDR condition of gift to Rockefeller Foundation; JDR can decide distribution of certain amount of money each year, later difficulties over original agreement. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Starr J. Murphy.

did.unittitle: Correspondence - Boards - Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Vivisectionists vs. anti-vivisectionists. Homeopathy - Dr. Biggar. John D. Rockefeller (JDR) interest, Frederick T. Gates "Notes on Homeopathy." JDR gifts to the Rockefeller Institute. Rockefeller Institute's work on several different diseases, personal letters from people asking for medical treatment and thanking for cures. Award to Simon Flexner and Rockefeller Institute from Prussian Royal Institute for Experimental Therapy. "The Rockefeller Institute - History, Organization and Equipment" booklet. JDR restored birthplace of Louis Pasteur in France. Rockefeller Institute establishing department for investigation of animal diseases. French "Chevalier de la Legion d'Honneur" to JDR for help of Rockefeller Institute in curing cerebro-spinal meningitis in France.

did.unittitle: Correspondence - Boards - Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Vivisectionists vs. anti-vivisectionists. Homeopathy - Dr. Biggar. John D. Rockefeller (JDR) interest, Frederick T. Gates "Notes on Homeopathy." JDR gifts to the Rockefeller Institute. Rockefeller Institute's work on several different diseases, personal letters from people asking for medical treatment and thanking for cures. Award to Simon Flexner and Rockefeller Institute from Prussian Royal Institute for Experimental Therapy. "The Rockefeller Institute - History, Organization and Equipment" booklet. JDR restored birthplace of Louis Pasteur in France. Rockefeller Institute establishing department for investigation of animal diseases. French "Chevalier de la Legion d'Honneur" to JDR for help of Rockefeller Institute in curing cerebro-spinal meningitis in France.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Study and treatment of hookworm in South through Hookworm Commission. John D. Rockefeller pledges. Opposition and resentment of work of the Hookworm Commission in South turned into acceptance and approval - newspaper comment. Correspondents include Wickliffe Rose, Frederick T. Gates, John D. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Biblical Recorder, 1917 book review, "Dr. Goodspeed's History of The University of Chicago." Asking John D. Rockefeller to visit University. 25th Anniversary celebration of University's founding, 1916. Gift of property on Cottage Grove Avenue. Correspondents include Starr J. Murphy, Harry Pratt Judson, Frederick T. Gates, Martin Ryerson.

did.unittitle: Correspondence - Boards - University of Chicago - Endowment

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Release agreement: John D. Rockefeller to University of Chicago. Smaller gifts in 1906, 1907. $10,000,000 gift in 1910. Correspondents include Harry Pratt Judson.
